awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Advanced Optical and Electrical Characterization of Novel Van der Waals Heterostructure Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description: With the development of nanotechnology and the shrinkage of device size, local optical and electrical properties are getting increasingly important in dictating the material functionalities, especially for the new class of material that are formed by stacking of material components of extremely small size in different shapes, often called nanotubes, nanowires, or dots. Their electrical and optical properties are sensitive to local imperfections such as impurities and defects. Conventional optical spectroscopy techniques face the difficulty in performing optical spectroscopy imaging with nanometer resolution. The research component of this CAREER award is focused on development of high-intensity, white-light source integrated with a scanning optical microscope to enable full-color imaging of nanoscale surface features. The small size of the light source and its fast decline in intensity over distance enable measurements with high resolution, high intensity and high signal to noise recording for exploring optical and electrical properties of various nanostructured materials. The project aims to integrate research components with various education and outreach activities with graduate and undergraduate students. The University of California at Riverside is a minority serving institution with large Hispanic student population and this project targets at increasing the participation of women and underrepresented minorities. 

Technical Description: Near-field scanning optical microscopy (NSOM) has been a powerful tool to break the diffraction limit of light for super-resolution images. This project aims to develop a new high-transmittance broad-bandwidth probe for a novel full-color NSOM, and to use it for investigation of the local optical and electrical properties of van der Waals (vdW) materials and heterostructure materials at the nanoscale. The research comprises a combination of vdW heterostructure fabrication, atomic-force-microscopy-integrated NSOM, scanning-tunneling-microscopy-integrated NSOM, and electrical transport measurements. By using this advanced optical characterization tool the research aims to elucidate: (i) the modified light-matter interaction in extremely confined systems; (ii) the optical and electrical properties of two-dimensional heterostructures, such as behavior of localized excitons or trions in graphene-MoS2 heterostructures; (iii) the electrical coupling between plasmonic mono-disperse clusters and graphene monolayer; and (iii) the band structure distributions in individual single-walled carbon nanotubes. The research components are integrated with various education and outreach activities with graduate, undergraduate and high school students, involving students from underrepresented minority groups.

por.por_cntn:
Throughout the duration of this award, we have made groundbreaking advancements in the field of near-field scanning optical microscopy (NSOM) and nanoscale optical characterization. Our work has primarily focused on improving the efficiency and resolution of NSOM, pushing the boundaries of what’s possible in optical microscopy and nanotechnology.

 

Intellectual Merit:

 

Our project achieved a remarkable milestone by developing an optical nanofocusing technique that concentrates light to a nanometer-scale volume with an unprecedented nanofocusing efficiency of up to 90% across the entire visible wavelength range. This high efficiency is crucial for enhancing the resolution and sensitivity of optical microscopy used in scientific research.

 

We successfully integrated this technique into various applications, demonstrating its versatility and effectiveness:

1. Tip-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (TERS): We achieved a spatial resolution of 1nm, allowing us to observe molecular structures and dynamics with near-atomic precision which was previously unattainable.

2. Scattering Spectroscopic Imaging: With a resolution of 6nm, this first-of-its-kind technique set a new standard in the field, enabling detailed study of material properties at the nanoscale. For the first time, transvers excitons with small scattering areas are imaged in carbon nanotubes.

3. 3D Photocurrent Microscopy: This application of our nanofocusing technique allowed for the mapping of electronic properties in nano-electronic devices with exceptional detail, significantly advancing our understanding of electrical properties of nanomaterials.

 

These technological advancements have not only enhanced our ability to characterize materials at the nanoscale but have also opened up new pathways in the study of novel quantum materials. The insights gained from these studies are critical for the development of next-generation nano-electronic and photonic devices.

 

Broader Impacts:

 

The broader impacts of our work are manifold, significantly affecting various sectors including education, industry, and beyond. We have integrated the principles and applications of our new microscopy techniques into university curriculums, enhancing the training and hands-on experience for both undergraduate and graduate students. This educational initiative prepares the next generation of scientists and engineers with advanced tools and knowledge. In industry, our techniques have potential applications in semiconductor manufacturing, materials science, and biotechnology, helping companies enhance product development from more efficient solar cells to faster electronic devices. Furthermore, our work has facilitated interdisciplinary research collaborations across physics, chemistry, materials science, and electrical engineering by enabling detailed studies of light-matter interactions at the nanoscale. Additionally, through publications, presentations, and open seminars, we have engaged with the broader scientific community and the public, raising awareness about the capabilities and implications of nanoscale optical characterization.

 

In conclusion, the outcomes of this NSF-funded project have significantly advanced the field of nanoscale optical microscopy, providing both the academic community and industry with powerful new tools to explore the properties of materials at unprecedented scales. The intellectual and broader impacts of our work demonstrate substantial advancements in both the understanding and application of nanotechnology, promising to drive innovation and discovery in numerous scientific and technological arenas.
